w:r.w:t: A key facet of healthy ALM is separating changes in development from those in testing and in production. Pipelines in Power Platform deploys the latest version of your solution across these environments, with the ability to add secure approvals and review changes before they’re deployed.
Note: in this lab you’ll only deploy from development to production, but in the real world it’s recommended to add an additional test stage. Other stages may also be added.
If you did not complete lab 2.1, import the ContosoRealEstate
_1_0_0_1.zip unmanaged solution in your development environment. This solution is available in your lab materials folder.
Configure environment records for the pipeline
Deploy using a Custom Host pipeline
Create an approval + SPN delegated deployment flow
Update pipeline to run as delegated
- Out of the box tenant-wide pipelines ghosted under a “platform host” configuration. These pipelines are configured by
for personal use. Personal pipelines cannot be extended, nor can they be shared with other makers in the tenant.
Pipelines configuration hosted under a custom environment, where Power Pipelines modules are installed by admins. Custom pipelines
are centrally governed by admins and shared with
visibility, like audit where a certain solution is deployed
. Custom host pipelines also retain backups of
artifacts in both Managed and Unmanaged forms
. Due to these reasons, custom hosts
capacity whereas the platform host doesn't.
make sure the Dev env is selected on the top right environment drop down
tab in the left-hand navigation blade

w:r.w:t: be extended to support approvals or delegations. Continue to the Custom
ipelines section to create extendable and shareable pipelines.
creating a new Custom Host Environment
This special-purpose environment acts as the
and management plane for all pipeline configuration, security, and run history.
install multiple Custom Host environments to separately manage pipelines for different business orgs or geographic locations
One host for the entire tenant is also acceptable as long as all environments are in the same geographic location.
In the Power Platform Admin Center (
Make sure you are on the
button to kick off a new environment creation with Power Platform Pipelines modules pre-installed.
In a real-world setting, using a Security Group is recommended to allow only authorized users access to this environment.

w:r.w:t: You will get a popup which
asks you to enable Managed Environments
on the target env. Remember, Pipelines are a ME only feature. Your Target environments must be enabled for ME to perform a deployment.
Only Power Platform and D365 Admins will see this prompt
, admins should enable ME on every environment they expect to be used in a pipeline. Steps to enable ME can be found
So far, the two types of pipelines we’ve explored
control over the deployment process to ensure production assets are
kept safe from unintentional or unapproved changes. For example,
administrators have permission to deploy to production, it’s important makers and developers do not have elevated access.
Or, maybe the process mandates an admin or change manager’s approval before a deployment to production can be initiated.
Let’s configure our pipeline to support these processes.

w:r.w:t: In this section, we will extend deployment pipelines we created in the sections above. Extending pipelines allows organizations to tailor pipelines to their unique needs. For example,
you can add approvals, deploy via service principals, and integrate with internal systems of record, Azure DevOps, GitHub, and much more.

Custom steps can be initiated at various stages of the pipeline. These steps are defined by Microsoft Dataverse business events. In Power Pipelines terminology, these initiation stages are called “Gated Extensions.” Here are the 3 available gated extensions:
running custom validation logic when a deployment request is submitted. Pipelines won’t export the solution from a development environment until this step is marked as completed.
This should only be used on the first stage of the pipeline.
Allows initiation of custom steps after a deployment has been triggered, but before installation begins on the target environment.
This gated extension can be used to trigger processes such as approvals before a solution is deployed to the target environment.
arries out deployments using a service principal or pipeline stage owner’s identity instead of the requesting maker’s
. This identity ensures makers can request deployments without elevated (or any) access within target environments. Requires approval from an authorized identity.

Each step of a pipeline deployment triggers a real-time event at the beginning and completion of the step for which you can initiate custom logic. Additional triggers are produced when gated extensions are enabled. These correspond to the custom step inserted when an extension is enabled on the pipeline stage.
The tables here indicate triggers and actions required for each extension
Any identity with access to update the deployment stage run record
Create a connection as the service principal or pipeline stage owner as configured on the pipeline stage. The pipeline stage owner must be an owner of the service principal in Microsoft Entra ID.
Any identity with access to update the deployment stage run record

to include an Approval step. Once we get the approval, we will perform a Delegated deployment using a

, you will see an additional step called
which we didn’t see when deploying
. This step will allow us to share objects within the Target environment directly from your Pipeline deployment.
Since we also added a cloud flow with two connections, we will also see a new Connections step when deploying.

we see the Connections step. Make sure you leave “Share connections with the service principal” checked as this is a requirement to associate new connections with the connection references in the UAT env.

w:r.w:t: Now, let’s approve our deployment. While there are many ways to

action on an Approval request in Power Platform, such as Approvals tab on Power Automate Maker portal, Approvals in Teams, or Approval email in Outlook, we will leverage new Advanced Approvals functionality in Deployments to approve the request. This is a great one-stop-shop like experience for Admins who are responsible for
reviewing approvals across multiple pipelines under the same Host or across multiple Hosts.
Here, you should find the approval you just initiated through your deployment pipeline
. Click on it to see the deployment details of the Approval request

w:r.w:t: > On the Model Driven App, select
On the Share Pane, scroll down and verify that the
: If you didn’t complete task 4, submit another deployment now. Run History should have at least two deployed versions.
While delegated deployments and approvals reduce the chances of breaking applications in production, mistakes can and do happen.
Let’s pretend the last deployment contained a critical breaking change and it needs to be rolled back. In this task, you’ll re-deploy the last known good version of your solution.
make sure you are in your development environment
from the left hand navigation blade

w:r.w:t: When the deployment panel opens, click Next until you get to the last screen, then
See prior Task for detailed steps if needed.
In a new tab, open Power Automate portal again and Approve the deployment request
Deployment is now in-progress. Wait until it finishes.
You may need to refresh the pipelines page.
Disaster averted! Now the prior version is deployed to production and you have time to fix the (hypothetical) issue and deploy an updated version when ready.
Navigate to Power Platform Admin Center (PPAC) at
In the Manage tab on the left hand side, click on
the environment where you want to enable Managed Environments
